author: By Alix Strauss
title: Why Do Couples Tie Cans to Wedding Cars?
description: Once used to show disapproval of a union, this clamorous custom now signifies a happy beginning for newlyweds.
content: Weddings are steeped in tradition, but where did those rituals come from? “Traditions,” a new column, explores the origins of various wedding customs from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport, Lisa Friedman and Keith Bradsher
title: Yellen Urges China to Step Up Climate Finance Investments
description: Janet Yellen, the Treasury secretary, said China, the largest emitter of greenhouse gases, can have “greater impact” tackling climate change by working with other nations.
content: The Biden administration called on China on Saturday to do more to help developing countries combat climate change, urging the world’s largest emitter of greenhouse gases to back international climate finance funds that it has so far declined to support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Community Land Trusts Are Working to Create New Homeowners
description: Born of the Civil Rights Movement, community land trusts are working to preserve neighborhoods and create new homeowners, from New York to California.
content: By the end of Shekinah Samaya-Thomas’s first date with her now-husband Chris, she had made two things very clear: She was going to get married — not necessarily to him — and she was going to own a house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: Drowning Is No. 1 Killer of Young Children. U.S. Efforts to Fix It Are Lagging.
description: Thirty years of progress in decreasing drowning deaths in the United States appears to have plateaued, and disparities in deaths among some racial groups have worsened.
content: Yadira Salcedo was born in Mexico to parents who did not know how to swim. As a child, she nearly drowned when she waded too deep in a backyard pool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Peter Nero, Pianist Who Straddled Genres, Is Dead at 89
description: He soared to popularity with a swinging hybrid of classics and jazz. He later conducted the Philly Pops, often with one hand while the other played piano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Carrière
title: In 1960s New York City, a Lost Young Woman Longs to Be Known
description: Nicole Flattery’s debut novel, “Nothing Special,” follows the protagonist through a menial and disorienting day job transcribing tape recordings — at Andy Warhol’s Factory.
content: In the Irish writer Nicole Flattery’s exquisitely disorienting debut novel, “Nothing Special,” Mae, the daughter of an alcoholic waitress, spends her youth in 1960s New York City riding up and down department store escalators, getting nowhere except deeper into her own dissatisfaction. She follows more decisive people into ambiguous situations — sexual, professional, existential. She falls into a job doing something that closely resembles nothing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Far-Right Parties Are Rising to Power Around Europe. Is Spain Next?
description: As Spain prepares for elections, some liberal European politicians fear that the hard-right Vox party could become the first right-wing party since the Franco era to enter Spain’s national government.
content: Last month, after Spain’s conservative and hard-right parties crushed the left in local elections, the winners in Elche, a small southeastern town known for an ancient sculpture and shoe exports, signed an agreement with consequences for the future of Spain — and the rest of Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Cluster Weapons U.S. Is Sending Ukraine Often Fail to Detonate
description: The Pentagon’s statements indicate that the cluster munitions that will be sent to Ukraine contain older grenades known to have a failure rate of 14 percent or more.
content: When the White House announced on Friday that it would agree to supply Ukraine with cluster munitions, it came after assurances from Pentagon officials that the weapons had been improved to minimize the danger to civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: A Doomsaying Theory Enters Pop Culture
description: “The Fourth Turning” was a curiosity when it was published in the 1990s. Its influence has grown since then, and a sequel is on the way.
content: Close watchers of “The Watcher,” the popular Netflix series about a couple who move to the New Jersey suburbs, only to be stalked in their dream home, may have caught the reference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Shaw
title: The Supreme Court’s Disorienting Elevation of Religion
description: The country will feel the impact of this sharp shift in the years ahead — and the court may not be done.
content: This term, the Supreme Court decided two cases involving religion: Groff v. DeJoy was a relatively low-profile case about religious accommodations at work; 303 Creative v. Elenis was a blockbuster case about the clash between religious exercise and principles of equal treatment. (The legal question was technically about speech, but religion was at the core of the dispute.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: The John Roberts Two-Step
description: He is very selective when it comes to race and racism.
content: In 2007, Chief Justice John Roberts wrote the majority opinion in Parents Involved v. Seattle School District No. 1, which struck down race-based “tiebreakers” in school admissions programs in Seattle and Louisville, Ky. “The way to stop discrimination on the basis of race,” Roberts famously wrote, “is to stop discriminating on the basis of race.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: A Top U.K. Newspaper Explores Its Ties to Slavery, and Britain’s
description: In a multimedia series, The Guardian becomes the latest British institution to confront — and apologize for — its role in the slave trade.
content: It is the kind of historical artifact that would be easy to miss: an old and fragile little book unearthed in the archives of the Derbyshire Record Office, in the East Midlands of England. The book, a commercial ledger from 1822, holds the names of enslavers who ran cotton plantations on islands along the coast of Florida, Georgia and South Carolina.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Canadian Court Rules Thumbs-Up Emoji Is a Contract Agreement
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 8, 2023.
content: “This case won’t definitively resolve what a thumbs-up emoji means, but it does remind people that using the thumbs-up emoji can have serious legal consequences.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro
title: He Worked for Years to Overturn Affirmative Action and Finally Won. He’s Not Done.
description: Edward Blum’s latest victory at the Supreme Court is the culmination of a long fight to take race out of college admissions. Is the workplace next?
content: Edward Blum has been working toward the end of race-based admissions in higher education for years. He first brought the issue of affirmative action before the Supreme Court in 2012, with Fisher v. University of Texas — a case he ended up losing. Since then, the 71-year-old legal activist has founded a group called Students for Fair Admissions, which just won at the Supreme Court against Harvard and the University of North Carolina, in a decision that effectively ended race-based affirmative action policies in American college admissions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Victor Wembanyama Gets Introduction to N.B.A. Fame and Game in Las Vegas
description: Wembanyama had the anticipation of fans and a turn in the tabloids, yet a more modest showing as he learns his new team.
content: The walls around Victor Wembanyama, as he sat for a news conference Friday night at the Thomas and Mack Center, were plastered with images of past winners of the Las Vegas Summer League tournament. There were N.B.A. stars who played there in the early days of their careers and a photo of LeBron James from 2018, when he showed up wearing gold shorts that said “Lakers” on the front in his first public appearance after signing with the team.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: U.S. confirms talks with Russia on prisoner swap for Evan Gershkovich, but tempers expectations.
description: The Biden administration and the family of the Wall Street Journal reporter take note of his reaching 100 days in jail.
content: The United States confirmed on Friday that it was in talks with Russia about a potential prisoner swap for the Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich, but cautioned that the discussions had not yet produced “a clear pathway to a resolution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Mack
title: Got a Flight? Don’t Even Think About Checking a Bag.
description: The ultralight packing trend says a lot about the state of travel these days.
content: I’m terrible at packing. Laughably terrible. Concerningly so. On a recent trip to Las Vegas with my boyfriend (I’m gay) and both our mothers (again, we are extremely gay) to see Adele (you get the idea), we both packed so much that you’d be forgiven for thinking we were moving there. I doubt Adele packed more, even though she semirelocated there for several months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh
title: Iowa Republicans Set the Date for the Party’s Caucuses — and It’s Early
description: The state party will hold a nominating contest in January, the earliest it has been held in recent campaign cycles.
content: Iowa Republicans voted on Saturday to hold their caucuses on Jan. 15, 2024, pushing the state’s first-in-the-nation nominating contest weeks earlier than in recent years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: In Ukraine, They’re Doctors; in Britain, They’re Unemployed
description: Often jobless or languishing in low-skilled posts, doctors who fled Russia’s invasion are forced to confront a difficult dilemma: see their skills go unused, or return to a country at war.
content: Dr. Samer al-Sheikh stared numbly at the photograph of himself on his phone. The doctor pictured at the operating table was now almost unrecognizable to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paulette Perhach
title: So You’re Going on a Trip You Can’t Afford
description: Here are a few strategies to help keep travel costs under control.
content: Teodora Pirciu didn’t order the wine she wanted at dinner, even though she was on vacation to enjoy herself. Instead, she had water. As she chewed her food, thoughts of her bank account gnawed at her mind. Ms. Pirciu knew she would insist on paying the check for her son and her new boyfriend. She just didn’t know if her credit card would be declined.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Washington, Josh Katz and Tom Giratikanon
title: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, July 1-7
description: Another example of how an excellent vocabulary is the currency of this realm.
content: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ravi Mattu
title: ‘Several Things Have Shocked Me’: An Ex-Insider on Business in China
description: Desmond Shum built a multibillion-dollar empire in the boom times, and says the economy is in far worse shape than outsiders realize.
content: Desmond Shum was one of China’s most well-connected businessmen. He and his former wife, Duan Weihong, used their relationships with top government officials to build a multibillion-dollar property development company during a golden age for entrepreneurs starting in the mid-1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: With Nothing Left to Lose, the Mets and the Padres Get Desperate
description: Outrageous payrolls created outlandish expectations, but two of baseball’s most disappointing teams are just hoping to end the first half on a high note.
content: Just as the experts would have predicted before the season began, the Mets and the Padres opened a series against each other to close the season’s first half as two of the hottest teams in baseball.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: After the Affirmative Action Ruling, Asian Americans Ask What Happens Next
description: No matter their views of race-conscious admissions, students were wary of the college application process — and some thought little would change.
content: Kawsar Yasin, a Harvard sophomore of Uyghur descent, found the Supreme Court decision last week banning race-conscious college admissions gut-wrenching.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard
title: After Supreme Court Rulings, Answering Reader Questions About Paying for College
description: Responses to queries about financial aid, 529 plans, need-blind schools and more.
content: The Supreme Court decisions that struck down affirmative action programs and President Biden’s student debt cancellation plan will affect millions of people, whether they’re about to apply for college or are trying to pay it off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Ramaswamy Investments Seem at Odds With His Position on ‘Woke’ Culture
description: The billionaire biotech mogul has railed against socially conscious companies. But his financial disclosure shows he has a stake in some of the leaders in the field.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, a Republican presidential candidate who made a fortune in the biotech industry, has caught the interest of primary voters with fiery critiques of the socially conscious practices of U.S. corporations, which he laid out in a book, “Woke, Inc.: Inside Corporate America’s Social Justice Scam.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Trump Asked About I.R.S. Inquiry of F.B.I. Officials, Ex-Aide Says Under Oath
description: In a court filing, John Kelly, who was a chief of staff under Donald Trump, said the former president had asked about having the tax agency look into Peter Strzok and Lisa Page.
content: John F. Kelly, who served as former President Donald J. Trump’s second White House chief of staff, said in a sworn statement that Mr. Trump had discussed having the Internal Revenue Service and other federal agencies investigate two F.B.I. officials involved in the investigation into his campaign’s ties to Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: With War as a Backdrop, a Russian Fencing Drama Plays Out in the U.S.
description: The departure of Russian fencers who object to their country’s invasion of Ukraine has created a stir at home and left their sporting futures in question.
content: Fencing is usually among the least visible Olympic events, but a year out from the Paris Games it is providing political, sporting and familial drama related to the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur and Claire Fahy
title: Megan Rapinoe Announces This is Her Last World Cup
description: The women’s national team star made an unexpected retirement announcement ahead of a U.S. friendly against Wales.
content: Megan Rapinoe, the iconic soccer star who has transcended her sport to become one of the most outspoken, accomplished and dynamic athletes of her generation, didn’t want to wait until the end to say this season would be the end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump and DeSantis Are Battling for Iowa Voters. And for Its Governor, Too.
description: Gov. Kim Reynolds has vowed to be neutral in 2024. But Donald Trump’s team views her as neutral in name only when it comes to Ron DeSantis and his wife.
content: When Kim Reynolds, the Republican governor of Iowa, stopped by a donor retreat that Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida held last year, no one paid it much mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Goodell
title: In Texas, Dead Fish and Red-Faced Desperation Are Signs of Things to Come
description: Extreme heat is the engine of planetary chaos. We ignore it at our peril.
content: In 2019, I happened to be visiting Phoenix on a 115-degree day. I had a meeting one afternoon about 10 blocks from the hotel where I was staying downtown. I gamely thought I’d brave the heat and walk to it. How bad could the heat really be? I grew up in California, not the Arctic. I thought I knew heat. I was wrong. After walking three blocks, I felt dizzy. After seven blocks, my heart was pounding. After 10 blocks, I thought I was a goner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Lauren McCarthy
title: Gunman on a Scooter Kills 1 and Wounds 3 in Queens and Brooklyn, Police Say
description: The random attacks, which unfolded over two hours, prompted a sprawling search for the suspect, who was arrested on Saturday afternoon, the police said.
content: A gunman killed one person and wounded three others on Saturday as he drove a scooter across Brooklyn and Queens, randomly firing at groups of people and at stores in a chaotic two-hour stretch before the police arrested him, the New York Police Department said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Letter From the President
description: A New York Times article that reported reinforcements at Soviet missile sites angered President John F. Kennedy, not because it was wrong, but because it was correct.
content: President John F. Kennedy was apoplectic. An article in The New York Times on July 26, 1962, told readers that the Soviet Union had begun reinforcing some intercontinental ballistic missile sites with extra concrete, increasing the odds that the launchpads could survive an American nuclear strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
title: On Ukraine War’s 500th Day, Russia Strikes and Zelensky Shows Defiance
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine shared a video of a trip to Snake Island in the Black Sea, a symbol of his country’s fierce resistance, as Russian shelling in the east killed at least seven.
content: Russian forces launched a deadly strike in eastern Ukraine on Saturday as President Volodymyr Zelensky marked the 500th day of the war with a show of defiance, sharing a video of himself visiting a Black Sea island that has become a potent symbol of his country’s resistance to the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Holder of Very Small Blueprints
description: Brandon Koppy tosses together a puzzling pastiche.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is Brandon Koppy’s first Saturday and second themeless grid for The New York Times. He has constructed some memorable themes — a cinematic Sunday and an unexpected Friday come to mind. A Saturday is a departure from his form, and it makes him one Tuesday puzzle away from constructing a crossword for every day of the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenna Gordon
title: In Guam, the U.S. Military Presence Is in Full View
description: A photographer spent three weeks documenting life on the island, which is a strategic location for American military operations.
content: In the North Atlantic, a tropical cyclone is called a hurricane. In the Western Pacific, it’s a typhoon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Sims and Rick Rojas
title: Rising Temperatures Threaten More Than Misery for Oldest Americans
description: A wave of extreme heat has posed particular perils for older people, who are uniquely susceptible to such conditions.
content: When the torrential rain stopped on Friday afternoon, Laura Lowry could see the steam rising off the wet pavement. She was on her front porch in the Fifth Ward neighborhood of Houston, desperate for relief from the relentless humidity and 91-degree heat. The air-conditioner in her house worked, but she and her husband, reliant on disability checks, couldn’t afford to run it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carmel Breathnach
title: I Was a Peachy’s Puffs Girl
description: It’s not easy to do your job when everyone around you is having a good time.
content: I hugged my father goodbye in Dublin and boarded a plane for New York. My best friend from college was with me. We had student work visas and a vague plan to make enough money to spend the summer in California. We had visions of swimming in the Pacific and walking across the Golden Gate Bridge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Four Killed in an Early Morning House Fire Outside Albany
description: The victims were a 5-year-old girl, two men and a woman. A teenage boy survived the fire, jumping to safety from a second-floor window.
content: An early morning house fire killed four people, including a 5-year-old girl, in New Scotland, N.Y., outside of Albany, on Saturday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: They’re Ready to Fight Again, on Artificial Legs
description: Even after so much loss, Ukrainian war veterans plan to return to the front.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — The Superhumans Center is full of war amputees learning to walk on artificial limbs or smoking cigarettes clutched in prosthetic fingers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sofia Quaglia
title: Missing Wings on an ‘Alien’ Beetle Pose an Evolutionary Mystery
description: The specimen is the first wingless male beetle ever found.
content: The insect in the small specimen collection of Lund University in Sweden looked out of place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: One Reason the U.S. Can’t Quit China? Chips.
description: Chipmakers are finding it increasingly hard to operate in China but say doing business in the country is still key to their survival.
content: In May, Micron Technologies, the Idaho chipmaker, suffered a serious blow as part of the U.S.-China technology war. The Chinese government barred companies that handle crucial information from buying Micron’s chips, saying the company had failed a cybersecurity review.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: A Thousand Words
description: Christina Iverson shows off a picture-perfect puzzle.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei and James Jackman
title: The Mango Is King of the Miami Summer
description: Those who sweat and suffer through June and July in South Florida are rewarded with mangoes blushing from trees in yards, streets and strip malls.
content: The air gets thick with humidity as summer arrives in South Florida. Evening thunder murmurs. The tropics begin to stir.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Why China Has a Giant Pile of Debt
description: A major lender abroad, China is facing a debt bomb at home: trillions of dollars owed by local governments, their financial affiliates, and real estate developers.
content: China, which has lent nearly $1 trillion to some 150 developing countries, has been reluctant to cancel large debts owed by countries struggling to make ends meet. That is at least in part because China is facing a debt bomb at home: trillions of dollars owed by local governments, their mostly off-the-books financial affiliates, and real estate developers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Chang
title: For a Tech Employee in Silicon Valley, a ‘Black Hole’ Looms Large
description: In Sarah Rose Etter’s novel “Ripe,” a 30-something writes marketing copy by day, but spends her nights diving deep into the void.
content: In Rachel Aviv’s “Strangers to Ourselves,” a woman describes mental health as “like your darkness is still there, but it’s almost like it’s next to you as opposed to your totality of being.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Is It a Meal? A Snack? No, It’s ‘Girl Dinner.’
description: Women across TikTok are showing off their suppers — snack plates made by one person, for the consumption and enjoyment of one person.
content: It’s 90 degrees outside, and you’re too hot and exhausted from a long day of work to cobble together a proper meal. Luckily you’re home by yourself — no kids, no roommates, no partners — and therefore can eat whatever you want for dinner, without having to consider the food preferences or nutrition needs of others. You grab a bag of popcorn, a glass of wine, some bread, some cheese and a hunk of chocolate, and settle into the couch for a night of snacking and watching TV. Is there anything more glorious? Welcome to “girl dinner.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: Six Are Dead After a Small Plane Crash in California
description: The authorities said the plane, which took off from Las Vegas, crashed outside of an airport in Murrieta, Calif., during the pilot’s second approach.
content: Six people were killed on Saturday after a small plane that was traveling from Las Vegas crashed near an airport in Murrieta, Calif., the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Terreri Ramos
title: What’s the Best Way to Buy My Rental Condo From the Landlord?
description: Due diligence is required, but a private sale such as this can have advantages.
content: Q: We have been renting a two-bedroom condo in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, for almost eight years, and our landlord is considering selling it to us. We’re interested in buying it, but we don’t know how to navigate a private sale. There’s been some wear and tear since we arrived, and the landlords haven’t done any improvements beyond necessary repairs and replacing broken appliances. Should we hire an appraiser and have a lawyer draft an offer letter? What is the best way to approach this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: What You Need to Know About the Dutch Government Collapse
description: The coalition parties couldn’t come to an agreement on the country’s migration policy. What were they fighting over and what comes next?
content: A political crisis erupted in the Netherlands on Friday night, with the prime minister offering the resignation of his government to the king, meaning there will be new elections in the fall. Here’s what you need to know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul and Anemona Hartocollis
title: What to Know About College Admissions Now That Affirmative Action Is Gone
description: Do extracurriculars help? How about being a guy? Getting into selective schools this year will look different. Here are a few answers to questions from readers.
content: With the Supreme Court decision banning race-conscious affirmative action, the college admissions process is about to change for everyone. Hundreds of colleges have stopped requiring standardized tests, essays are likely to be much more important, and admissions decisions could become much more subjective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Turning In
description: As we age, our sleep needs change. Nights when we sleep more than we’re up become as precious as they are elusive.
content: How did you sleep last night? Did you slumber lavishly, temperature and temperament aligned, waking with the sun? Or was it one of those stormy-seas nights, dreams indistinguishable from waking-life worries, tangled covers, eyes on the clock?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Nikki McCray-Penson, Basketball Star and Coach, Dies at 51
description: After a standout college career at the University of Tennessee, she won two Olympic gold medals, played nine years in the W.N.B.A. and was the head coach at two universities.
content: Nikki McCray-Penson, an all-American point guard for the powerhouse University of Tennessee women’s basketball team, a two-time Olympic gold medalist and a three-time All-Star in the W.N.B.A., died on Friday. She was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni, Ravi Mattu and Lauren Hirsch
title: Mark Zuckerberg’s Threads Poses a Conundrum for Regulators
description: Meta’s new rival to Twitter has been hugely popular among consumers but raises awkward questions about how big tech companies expand.
content: The rivalry between Mark Zuckerberg and Elon Musk went into overdrive this week after Meta rolled out Threads, a Twitter rival that on its first day became the most rapidly downloaded app ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Pearson
title: How to Make a Staycation Feel Like an Actual Break
description: A ‘mental flip’ can help make your time off more restorative, even if you’re not traveling far.
content: American workers are notoriously lousy at taking time off. A recent survey by the Pew Research Center found that 46 percent of employees with paid time off did not use all of their allotted days. Yes, vacations are good for you. But balancing work and school schedules can be tricky, and jet-setting is not typically within the average family’s budget.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Can the Republican Party Reverse Course?
description: Readers discuss a guest essay by a former judge urging the G.O.P. to “put country over party.”
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arielle Domb
title: How a Taxidermist Spends Sundays
description: For Divya Anantharaman, who runs a taxidermy business in Brooklyn, regular manicures are part of the job.
content: Growing up in a cramped Miami apartment, Divya Anantharaman would spend hours perched by the kitchen window, gazing at the birds passing by.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Alone in an Empty House, Female Real Estate Agents Face Danger
description: Most sexual harassment comes from potential clients, and agents say they are vulnerable to abuse in an industry that offers few protections.
content: Sara Ghodsi sold auto parts before moving to San Diego and becoming a real estate agent. She didn’t have to sit in an office all day, made a good income and had the freedom to work on her own schedule, all of which she enjoyed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Transgender Care Ban Allowed to Take Effect in Tennessee, Appeals Panel Says
description: The ruling on Saturday is the first time a federal court has allowed a law banning transition care to fully go into effect, amid a flurry of legal challenges across the country.
content: A federal appeals panel on Saturday said a Tennessee law that would ban hormone therapy and puberty blockers for transgender youth could go into effect, marking the first time a federal court has allowed a law banning transition care to fully take hold in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to This American Life: Americans in Paris
description: And the best of the archive, found in our new audio app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling and provides news, depth and serendipity. It is available to Times news subscribers on iOS. If you haven’t already, download the app here and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein and Jane Stockdale
title: Rain Keeps Coming at Wimbledon, but the Court Crews Have It Covered
description: The court services crews at the All England Club deploy 18 tarps at a time to keep precious grass courts dry. They’re not above fetching a player a banana or a soft drink, either.
content: High atop the outer south wall of Centre Court at Wimbledon, a small rectangle has been cut away in the lush, green ivy, revealing a digital number that few, if any, of the 42,000 spectators entering the grounds each day of the tournament ever notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: A Peek Inside Canada’s Most Complex Heritage Restoration Job
description: The multibillion-dollar restoration and expansion of Canada’s main Parliament building is finishing its first phase.
content: On Canada Day, about 100,000 people, including Prime Minister Justin Trudeau, made their way to a concert stage in front of the Canadian War Museum for a day of musical performance, occasional speeches and, finally, fireworks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Making Them Laugh, and Swoon
description: A year ago, Matt Rife was just another struggling road comedian. Then he blew up on TikTok.
content: The one-nighters were starting to blur together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: It’s Seven Grandkids, Mr. President
description: Cherishing family means all of your family.
content: WASHINGTON — Even my Republican sister is not immune to Joe Biden’s gregarious Irish charm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Audrey Wollen
title: Rachel Ingalls Considers a Fix for Marital Ennui: Sex Robots
description: Her novella “In the Act” explores love and fantasy in unusual guises.
content: The robot dream girl, built by the mad scientist to be his ideal romantic partner, simplifies the clumsy business of sexual negotiation: She agrees to everything. Permanently, preternaturally consensual, she nullifies the possibility of rape. A relief, and a horror.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Toronto Prepares for Its ‘Beyoncé Weekend’
description: Beyoncé is starting the North American leg of her Renaissance tour on Saturday in Toronto, where fans are giddy and the gridlock is imminent.
content: If it were left up to fans, one of the incoming Toronto mayor’s first acts would be to declare a municipal holiday in honor of Beyoncé’s latest tour stop in the city to kick off her North American shows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Pom Klementieff Is Hooked on Skydiving, Thanks to Tom Cruise
description: The “Guardians of the Galaxy” actress, who plays a villain in the new “Mission: Impossible” movie, considers “Gone Girl” feel-good viewing.
content: Pom Klementieff had just checked into her hotel room in London, and she was still relishing the butter chicken she had consumed an hour ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Segal
title: The End of the Magic World’s 50-Year Grudge
description: In 1973, Uri Geller claimed to bend metal with his mind on live television. Skeptics couldn’t beat him. Now they’ve joined him.
content: In 1973, a young man named Uri Geller appeared on one of the BBC’s most popular television shows, “The Dimbleby Talk-In,” and announced that the laws of Newtonian physics did not apply to him. Or that, at least, was the implication. A handsome 26-year-old Israeli, dressed casually and flanked by a pair of academics, Mr. Geller performed a series of bewildering feats using nothing more, he said, than his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Has Wimbledon’s Beguiling Grass Robbed the Grand Slam of Its Magic?
description: Wimbledon, long considered the most prestigious tournament in the sport, has some of the world’s best players feeling “bad at tennis” and unprepared to win at the All England Club.
content: Casper Ruud, the three-time Grand Slam tournament finalist, took a nontraditional approach to getting ready for Wimbledon, which is widely considered the most prestigious tournament in tennis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: This Ballerina Has a Mission: ‘Being as Human as Possible’
description: Cassandra Trenary, an American Ballet Theater principal dancer, pulls classical dance into the present through the drama of being real.
content: There was a point, during Cassandra Trenary’s debut as Juliet last summer at American Ballet Theater, when it became easy to forget that she was performing the role at all. She just was Juliet: furious, despondent, at her wit’s end.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 8, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 8, 2023.
content: An article on Wednesday about hotel workers on strike in Los Angeles misstated the number of hotel workers who walked off their jobs over the weekend. It was several thousand, not 15,000.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Oleksandr Chubko
title: Bucha Gets a Remake, but Pain Lingers Behind the Facade
description: More than a year after Ukrainian forces wrested back Bucha from Russian troops, the town is physically transformed. But so much remains unresolved.
content: BUCHA, Ukraine — There is a line of tidy houses on Vokzalna Street, where crumbling homes once lined a roadway littered with burned-out Russian tanks. There are neat sidewalks and fresh pavement with blue and yellow bunting hanging overhead. And there are backhoes and bulldozers plowing across a construction site where a new home goods store will replace a previous one that was burned to the ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Claire Moses
title: Collapse of Dutch Government Highlights Europe’s New Migration Politics
description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte resigned after his coalition partners rejected his tough new line on refugees, favoring his own political future, critics say, over compromise.
content: The collapse of a Dutch coalition government over a proposed refugee policy has once again underscored the potency of immigration as an arbiter of Europe’s politics and how stopping far-right parties from capitalizing on it is a growing problem for mainstream politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: James F. Dobbins, Leading Authority on Nation Building, Dies at 81
description: His Foreign Service career took him on a tour of world hot spots, including Somalia, Haiti, the Balkans and Afghanistan, where he led efforts to rebuild war-torn countries.
content: James F. Dobbins, an American diplomat whose career took him to Haiti, Afghanistan and many points in between, and who was both respected as a peace negotiator and widely regarded as the world’s leading authority on nation building, died on Monday  in Washington. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Yellen Calls on China to Work With the U.S. to Address Climate Change
description: Janet L. Yellen, the secretary of the Treasury, said that the United States and China had a joint responsibility to back international climate finance funds to combat climate change.
content: Janet L. Yellen, the secretary of the Treasury, said that the United States and China had a joint responsibility to back international climate finance funds to combat climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Gunman in Custody After Killing One Person in Queens
description: A gunman on a scooter randomly fired at people and stores within a two-hour period across Brooklyn and Queens, the New York Police Department said. Several others were injured, with one in critical condition.
content: A gunman on a scooter randomly fired at people and stores within a two-hour period across Brooklyn and Queens, the New York Police Department said. Several others were injured, with one in critical condition.
source.name: The New York Times
